title: Jermain Defoe will consider Sunderland future if they are relegated as he looks to keep alive his England dream of playing at the World Cup
text:
Sport Jermain Defoe will consider Sunderland future if they are relegated as he looks to keep alive his England dream of playing at the World Cup Defoe has been the star performer for Sunderland this season and his 14 goals have seen him earn a recall to the England squad for the first time since 2013 Share Defoe has been in superb form this season (Photo: REUTERS) Share   
Jermain Defoe will consider his Sunderland future if they are relegated as he wants to keep alive his dream of playing for England at the World Cup next summer. 
Defoe, 34, last played for England back in 2013, but was handed a recall to the squad by Gareth Southgate following his superb run of form for the struggling north east club this season. 
The prolific forward has still managed to score 14 goals despite their perilous position in the table and received a phone call from Southgate telling him he was back in the squad for the double-header against Germany and Lithuania. Defoe is the second highest English scorer in the top flight behind Harry Kane (Photo: Getty) 
Defoe has made 55 appearances for his country and says he would love the chance to play at another major tournament - but knows he needs to be playing in the Premier League if he is to achieve that goal. 
Defoe said: "Obviously you have to be realistic and to get into any squad it is based on merit and you need to be playing at the top level. 
"When I went to Toronto (in MLS in early 2014) I missed out on going to the World Cup and it was a hard call to take. I would say I probably need to be playing in the Premier League but we will see what happens. 
"The boys I'm competing against are playing in the Premier League and playing in Europe and probably that's why I missed out on the last World Cup. You probably need to be playing in the Premier League. Gareth Southgate has been impressed with Defoe's form this season (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
"I've been blessed to have gone to two major tournaments Like I said, just never giving up really, just always keeping my head down, working hard and just having that hope that I'll get back in. I'm back here and I'm delighted. I know how important it is to play for your country. 
"Just going to a major tournament, travelling, getting to the hotels, playing the games - it's something you've always wanted to do from being a kid, growing up watching the great players over the years. Playing in the major tournaments, going out and emulating the players you've seen on TV. 
"Being lucky enough to have experienced it, you just want it more and more. So for me, if I do get an opportunity to go to another major tournament, it'd be a dream.‚Äù Defoe's last England appearance came against Chile back in 2013 (Photo: The FA via Getty) 
Sunderland remain rooted to the foot of the table, but Defoe has still been able to show his quality and his 14 goals makes him the second highest English scorer in the top flight behind Harry Kane. 
Defoe is now hoping his recall to the England squad will help get his Sunderland team-mates off his back as he has refused to change the flag on his boots!
